container.heading: Certificate of Registration for Continuing Care Facilities and Providers

section.heading: Definitions.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Act" means Human Services Article, Title 10, Subtitle 4, Parts I—V and VII—IX, Annotated Code of Maryland.

"Actuarial balance sheet" means a balance sheet that uses actuarial principles and practices to determine the value of certain items in the balance sheet based on actuarial techniques involving reasonable assumptions about contingencies, inflation, and the time value of money as applied to current subscribers, which items include the present value of:
Future periodic fees;
The costs of providing promised future services; and
The obligation for refundable entrance fees.
"Agreement" means the residence and care agreement between the provider and subscriber that is the contract to provide continuing care.

"Assisted living unit" means a unit in which the services rendered will require the provider to be licensed either as an assisted living program under Health-General Article, §19-1805, Annotated Code of Maryland, or as a domiciliary care home under Health-General Article, §19-318, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Authority Recognized by the Department.

"Authority recognized by the Department" means a person whom the Department determines has the knowledge and experience of the continuing care industry necessary to produce the particular materials required by a given regulation in this chapter.
"Authority recognized by the Department" includes an independent consultant or an employee of a provider or related entity.
"Authorized officer" means an individual holding one of the following positions with a provider:
An officer;
A general partner;
Any individual that serves on the governing body; or
A trustee of the provider.

"Certified financial statement" means a financial statement, prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles by an independent certified public accountant, that includes an audit opinion, balance sheet, income statement, statement of cash flows, and the related notes to the financial statement.
"Certified financial statement for the most recent fiscal year for which a certified financial statement is available" means:
For providers who annually receive a certified financial statement within 120 days of the end of their fiscal year, the most recently dated financial statement; and

For any other providers, assuming that a certified financial statement is obtainable under generally accepted auditing standards, a certified financial statement that is not greater than 120 days old.
"Chief executive officer" means the individual whose primary responsibility is to oversee all aspects of the operation of the provider.
"Committee" means Financial Review Committee.
"Continuing care" means furnishing shelter and services to the public under all the following conditions:
Services consist of shelter plus health services;
Health services provided shall include at least one of the following services:
Medical and nursing services,
A formal arrangement between the provider and a nursing home by which the nursing home grants priority to subscribers for admission to the nursing home, or
Assistance with the activities of daily living other than the provision of meals;
Services may be paid for by the following methods:
An entrance fee in advance of receipt of services,
Regular periodic charges which guarantee health services whenever needed,
Purchase of services at the option of the subscriber as services are needed, or
Any combination of the arrangements in §B(11)(c)(i)—(iii) of this regulation;
Services are offered to individuals who are:
60 years old or older, and
Not related to the provider by blood or marriage;
Services are offered for:
The life of the subscriber, or
A period in excess of 1 year; and
Services are offered under a written agreement that may require periodic charges and shall require:
A transfer of assets from the subscriber to the provider,
An entrance fee, or
Both a transfer of assets and an entrance fee.
Control.
"Control" means the power to direct, or cause the direction of, the management and policies of a provider through the ownership of voting securities, by contract, or otherwise.

"Control" includes a parent or sole corporate member of a corporation directly participating in the initiation or approval of policies directly affecting the operations, including approval of budgets or approval of the chief executive officer of the provider.
"Department" means the Maryland Department of Aging.
"Deposit" means a portion of the entrance fee.
Deposit Agreement.

"Deposit agreement" means the preliminary agreement between the subscriber and the provider by which the provider reserves for the subscriber the right to contract for continuing care in return for payment by the subscriber of a deposit.
"Deposit agreement" includes any agreement of similar form and use, regardless of title, including priority agreement and reservation agreement.
Entrance Fee.
"Entrance fee" means a sum of money or other consideration, other than a surcharge, paid initially or in deferred payments, that:
Assures a subscriber continuing care for a term of more than 1 year or for life; and
Is at least three times the weighted average of the monthly cost of the periodic fees charged for independent living and assisted living units.
"Entrance fee" includes a fee of similar form and application, regardless of title.

"Escrow agreement" means an agreement between the provider and a financial institution by which deposits and entrance fees are held in Maryland by the financial institution until release is permitted by law or regulation.
"Expansion" means any single new capital addition, excluding renovation and normal repair and maintenance, that meets either of the following criteria:

If independent living or assisted living units are to be constructed, then the number of units to be constructed is less than or equal to 25 percent of the number of existing independent living units and assisted living units; or
If independent living or assisted living units are not to be constructed, then the total projected cost is an amount that is more than the sum of:

10 percent of the total operating expenses of the facility, less depreciation, amortization, and interest expense, as shown on the certified financial statement for the most recent fiscal year for which a certified financial statement is available, and
The amount of the existing reserves properly allocable to, and so allocated for, the expansion.
"Facility" means a physical plant and related grounds used to provide continuing care in accordance with this chapter.

"Financial difficulty" means the current or impending financial condition of a provider which currently impairs or may impair the ability of the provider to meet existing or future obligations to subscribers or other creditors.
"Fiscal year" means the fiscal year of the provider.

"Generally accepted accounting principles" means those accounting principles and practices adopted by the Financial Accounting Standards Board and the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, which include the principles expressed in the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants' "Audit and Accounting Guide for Health Care Organizations".

"Governing body" means a board of directors, board of trustees, or similar group that ultimately directs the affairs of a provider, but whose members are not required to have an equity interest in the provider.
"MDH" means the Maryland Department of Health.
"MHCC" means the Maryland Health Care Commission.
"New units" means independent living or assisted living units that are:
Part of a new facility; or
Additions to an existing facility that are greater than 25 percent of the number of existing independent and assisted living units at the existing facility.
"Person" means an individual, firm, association, corporation, company, trust, partnership, limited liability company, public body, or other business or nonprofit entity.
"Processing fee" means a one-time fee charged by the provider to determine the financial, mental, and physical eligibility of an individual seeking admission into a facility.
"Provider" means a person who undertakes to provide continuing care and who is an:
Owner or operator of a facility; or
Applicant for, or the holder of, a certificate of registration.
"Qualified actuary" means a member in good standing of the American Academy of Actuaries.
"Records" means the information, books, and data maintained for the operation of the facility or the provider in accordance with this chapter.
"Renewal" means the renewal of a certificate of registration required annually to permit the provider to continue to offer continuing care to the public.
Renovation.

"Renovation" means any single capital improvement to, or replacement of, all or part of the existing facility that does not increase the number of independent living or assisted living units and for which the total projected cost is an amount that is more than the sum of:

20 percent of the total operating expenses of the facility, less depreciation, amortization, and interest expense, as shown on the certified financial statement for the most recent fiscal year for which a certified financial statement is available; and
The amount of the existing reserves properly allocable to, and so allocated for, the renovation.
"Renovation" does not include normal repair and maintenance.
"Secretary" means Secretary of Aging.
"Subscriber" means an individual for whom continuing care is purchased under an agreement.

"Surcharge" means a separate and additional charge, other than a second-person entrance fee, imposed simultaneously with the entrance fee, that may be required of some, but not all, subscribers because of a condition or circumstance that applies only to those subscribers.
Unit.

"Unit" means a suite, room, cottage, apartment, or any other type of quarters that is located at a facility and in which a subscriber is to reside while receiving the benefits of a continuing care agreement, including quarters for independent living, assisted living, and comprehensive care.

"Unit" includes individual beds licensed for domiciliary care, assisted living, and comprehensive care so that each assisted living bed, domiciliary care bed, and comprehensive care bed constitutes a unit.

section.heading: General Requirements to Offer Continuing Care.

para.text: A provider may not offer continuing care, enter into or renew an agreement for continuing care, begin construction for a new facility, or collect deposits for continuing care without having secured the necessary feasibility study approval or certificate of registration from the Department.
Submissions.
The submissions described in this section shall be filed with and approved by the Department.

Statement of Intent. Any person that intends to offer continuing care agreements for new units or to file a feasibility study under Regulation .05 of this chapter shall file a statement of intent with the Department at least 30 days before submission of the feasibility study.

Application for Approval of Feasibility Study. A provider shall obtain approval by the Department of a feasibility study before a provider may collect deposits or enter into deposit agreements for new units. Deposits for new units collected after the feasibility study has been approved shall be maintained in an escrow account held in Maryland in a federally insured depository under an escrow agreement approved by the Department.
Application for Preliminary Certificate. A preliminary certificate of registration is required before a provider may offer or enter into continuing care agreements for any new units.
Application for Initial Certificate. An initial certificate of registration is required before a provider may operate a facility offering continuing care.
Request for Approval to Use Deposits. A provider may not use deposits collected from subscribers for new units until:
The Department has issued the provider an initial certificate of registration for any new units;
Construction of the new units has been completed;
A certificate of occupancy or equivalent has been obtained from the appropriate local jurisdiction; and
Appropriate licenses or certificates required by MHCC, MDH, and the Department have been issued.
Application for Renewal of Certificate of Registration. A current certificate of registration is required to continue to operate or maintain a facility offering continuing care.
All approvals and certificates of registration issued by the Department shall approve or certify a specific number of units designated by type as:
Independent living;
Assisted living;
Comprehensive care; or
Other type approved by the Department.
A provider who operates or plans to operate more than one facility shall file separately for each facility the submissions and applications set forth in §B of this regulation.

A provider may not begin construction of an expansion or renovation unless the provider has complied with the applicable provisions of Regulations .15 and .17 of this chapter. Any new capital addition that in a 2-year period will result in the construction of a number of independent living and assisted living units that is greater than 25 percent of the number of existing independent living and assisted living units is considered new development, is subject to §B of this regulation and Regulations .03—.09 of this chapter, and requires an initial certificate of registration to include the new units. Any new capital addition that is not an expansion and that does not involve the construction of independent living or assisted living units is not subject to review under Regulation .15 or .17 of this chapter. Any capital improvement or replacement that is not a renovation is not subject to Department review under Regulation .15 or .17 of this chapter. An expansion of comprehensive care beds, regardless of number, requires a certificate of need or a certificate of need exemption from MHCC.
A provider may not offer or enter into a deposit agreement or an agreement, unless the terms have been approved by the Department.
A provider may not disseminate advertising or circulars which are deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead.
Special Conditions.

A provider applying for a certificate of registration whose past or current performance in the operation of a continuing care facility, whether that facility is located within or outside of Maryland, causes the Secretary to question the provider's financial or administrative ability to maintain a continuing care facility in compliance with this chapter, shall submit to the Department evidence demonstrating financial or administrative soundness, or both, as the Secretary considers appropriate. This information is sought only in special circumstances and is not required as a matter of course.
The Secretary shall:
Approve the application unconditionally;
Require the provider to use the services of a management firm; or
Deny the application.

A management firm required by §H(2)(b) of this regulation shall be selected by the provider subject to the approval of the Department. Approval of a management firm that currently does business in Maryland, has projects in good standing under the Act, and which has not had a fiduciary or consultant relationship with the Department may not be denied without cause. The management firm shall assume full operational and financial responsibilities. The Secretary may not require utilization of a management firm for a period that exceeds 24 months.
A party aggrieved by a decision of the Secretary under this regulation has the right to appeal under Regulation .36 of this chapter.
A provider who is denied approval of submissions required by §B(3), B(4), or E of this regulation may reapply 1 year after the date of denial.

section.heading: Preliminary Certificate of Registration.

para.text: Process to Obtain a Preliminary Certificate of Registration. A person shall file a:
Statement of intent under Regulation .04 of this chapter;
A feasibility study under Regulation .05 of this chapter; and
An application under Regulation .06 of this chapter.
Forms and Fees for Feasibility Study and Application.
A feasibility study and an application for a preliminary certificate of registration shall be submitted with forms provided by the Department.
When new units are to be created and the project is neither an expansion nor a renovation, the following fees shall accompany the feasibility study:
$14,000 for 1—99 new units;
$20,000 for 100—199 new units;
$30,000 for 200—499 new units;
$40,000 for 500—999 new units; and
$50,000 for 1,000 or more new units.
The Department may charge an additional fee, not to exceed the original fee, if resubmission of a feasibility study to the Department is required due to:
Significant changes in the assumptions upon which the feasibility study was based;
Correction of significant errors in the feasibility study; or
A significant omission in the original feasibility study submission.

section.heading: Statement of Intent to Apply for a Preliminary Certificate.

para.text: Statement of Intent. Any person that intends to offer continuing care agreements for new units or to file a feasibility study under Regulation .05 of this chapter shall file a statement of intent with the Department at least 30 days before submission of a feasibility study. If a feasibility study is not filed by the provider within 60 days after the statement of intent is filed, a new statement of intent shall be filed with the Department at least 30 days before submission of a feasibility study.
Contents. A statement of intent shall contain, at a minimum, the following information:
The name of both the provider and the proposed facility;
Whether entrance fees will be refundable or nonrefundable;
The types of agreements proposed, such as extensive, modified, or fee-for-service;
The number of proposed units by type, such as independent living, assisted living, and comprehensive care;
Whether the provider is proposed to be for-profit or nonprofit;
The name of the management company, if any, that will operate the facility;
If applicable, the name of the:
Development company proposing to develop the facility;
Marketing consultant;
Provider's attorney; and
Preparer of the feasibility study, along with the preparer's qualifications;
A statement indicating whether any proposed comprehensive care beds will need a new certificate of need or a new exemption from the certificate of need requirements of MHCC; and
Any further information the Department requires.

section.heading: Feasibility Study.

para.text: The feasibility study shall be prepared in a form satisfactory to the Department, by an authority recognized by the Department, and shall include at least the following information:
A statement of the purpose for the proposed project or construction;
A summary of the proposed project, which shall include the following information:
A description of the proposed project;

A statement regarding any affiliation of the provider with a religious, charitable, or other nonprofit organization, and the extent to which the organization will be responsible for the financial and contractual obligations of the provider;
The location, address, city, county, size, and description of the site;
The number of proposed independent living units, assisted living units, and comprehensive care units; and
A description of any common areas and community spaces to be provided such as lobbies, dining rooms, doctor's Departments, convenience stores, craft rooms, meeting rooms, and exercise rooms;
A summary of the organizational structure of the proposed provider and development team, which shall include the following information:
The ownership of the provider, including whether it is for-profit;
The owner of the facility if other than the provider;

A description of the qualifications of the proposed manager or management company if the facility is, or will be, managed on a day-to-day basis by a person other than an individual directly employed by the provider, including the business experience the manager or management company has operating or managing similar facilities; and
A description of the qualifications of any other person who is significantly involved in the development of the facility;
A summary description of the location of the proposed project, which shall include the following information:
A map indicating the location of the proposed community;
A general description of the surrounding land use and the access to public transportation and highways; and
The availability and attractiveness of proximate services such as shopping, cultural, recreational, and educational facilities, health services, churches, theaters, and libraries;
A full description of the site of the proposed project which shall include the following information:
The size;
A general description of its boundaries;
Any access roads;
From whom the site was acquired and the former usage of the site;
Any unique characteristics of the site such as water, ponds, or woods;
Any current buildings, services, or facilities at the site and their intended use;
A site development plan indicating existing features and structures, if any, and the proposed new facilities;
Any planned post-application development;
The availability of utilities and proximity to site;
The zoning status and any required changes; and
The type of site control or ownership, including such information as:
The date the site was acquired,
The date it was optioned,
The terms of any rights of first refusal, or
Any other significant terms of the acquisition;
A summary of any independent living component of the facility, which shall include the following:
A broad description of the type and number of independent living units, such as cottages, clustered duplexes, or apartments;
A description of the type of construction that may be used, such as new construction or rehabilitation of existing structures;
The square footage of the independent living area that corresponds to each type of independent living unit offered;
A summary of the access to the independent living units; and
The schematics of each different type of independent living unit;
A summary of the common and service areas of the facility, which shall include the following:
A listing of the square footage of the common, service, administrative, and any other non-health-related areas and their location in relation to the independent living units; and
The schematics of the common, service, administrative, and any other non-health-related areas;
A summary of any plans for assisted living or comprehensive care units, which shall include the following:
A general description of the square footage of each type of unit and the location of each type in relation to the independent living units and the common areas;
The number of assisted living and comprehensive care units categorized as:
Private,
Semiprivate, and
Suites;
The total number of assisted living and comprehensive care units;
A description of the types of any doctors' Departments that will be in the facility; and
The schematics of any space for assisted living, comprehensive care, or doctors' Departments;
A summary of the services that will be included in the monthly service fee;
A summary of the ancillary services that will not be included in the monthly service fee;
A statement describing any plans the provider has to require a subscriber to have long-term care insurance or supplement health insurance coverage;
A statement describing any plans the provider has to become Medicare or Medicaid certified;
A statement describing any plans the provider has to offer priority access to health-related services at an offsite location;
A statement describing any plans to delay the refund of any entrance fees until the resale of a subscriber's unit;
A study that demonstrates a market exists for the proposed project, which study shall include:
A description of the primary and secondary market area as defined by the provider;

A table of population information including age, sex, number, income distribution, and trends of the total population and individuals 60 years old and older within the primary and secondary market area;

A calculation of the potential impact on the proposed project of existing facilities, facilities for which letters of intent have been filed with the Department, and other projects that offer similar services in the primary and secondary market area, which calculation shall include the following information for each facility in the primary and secondary markets:
The number of independent living units, assisted living units, and comprehensive care units,
The opening date or proposed opening date of the facility,
The area marketed to,
The utilization experience,
The amount and type of entrance fees and monthly service fees, and
The services offered;
A calculation of the market penetration rate for the proposed facility for both the primary and secondary markets;
A table of home values in the primary and secondary market area;
A description of the minimum age, income, and net worth eligibility requirements for the anticipated subscribers of the proposed project;
A description of new entrant assumptions by age, sex, and couple ratio;
A description of the results of testing the potential demand and acceptance of the proposed project's location, services, and concept characteristics;

If the area in which the facility is to be built has limited continuing care experience, a comparison with a demographically similar area that has experience with continuing care communities that shows the:
Similarities and dissimilarities of the two markets, and

Experiences of one or more continuing care retirement communities in the comparable market, including their initial utilization experience and the penetration rates of their continuing care units into the eligible population; and

A statement describing the estimated presales period, including when the provider projects it will have executed agreements and collected at least 10 percent of the entrance fee for at least 65 percent of the independent living units;
A plan demonstrating the financial feasibility of the proposed project including the following:

The anticipated costs of constructing or acquiring the proposed project, including all related costs such as land costs, construction costs, architectural and engineering fees, financing expenses, marketing costs, legal and administrative costs, furnishings and equipment costs, fees and permits, and other costs;
The anticipated sources and uses of funds to finance the proposed project, including documentation of the financial resources of the provider;
A description of the proposed financing, including anticipated terms and costs of financing the proposed project;

Projected financial statements that are based on the information required in §(A)(17)(b) of this regulation and prepared in accordance with both §C of this regulation and generally accepted accounting principles;
A schedule of anticipated fees for a 10-year period, including any proposed escalator or other automatic adjustment provisions;
For each type of unit proposed to be offered, a schedule of the anticipated monthly move-ins until full occupancy is reached;
A description of the terms of the lease, if the provider is planning to lease the facility;
The estimated start and completion dates for the construction of the proposed project;
The initial proposed occupancy date; and
A statement indicating compliance with the requirements of Regulation .20 of this chapter;
Except as provided in §B of this regulation, an actuarial study, prepared or reviewed by a qualified actuary, which includes:

A cohort pricing analysis which demonstrates that for a typical cohort of new subscribers the sum of the entrance fees paid at occupancy plus the actuarial present value at occupancy of periodic fees exceeds the actuarial present value at occupancy of the costs of performing all obligations assumed by the provider, with appropriate provision for surplus;
Supporting detailed documentation for the cohort pricing analysis required in §A(17)(a) of this regulation, including:

A projection of future population flows and health care bed needs, for the first 20 years, using appropriate inflation factors, mortality, morbidity, withdrawal, and other demographic assumptions, and
A description of the actuarial data, assumptions, and methods used to create the projection;
Cash flow projections for a 20-year period, which project positive cash balances; and

The opinion of the actuary that the data and assumptions used are appropriate, the methods employed are consistent with sound actuarial principles and practices, and provision has been made for all actuarial liabilities and related statement items;
A copy of the proposed deposit agreement between the provider and prospective subscribers governing the disposition of the escrowed funds and the interest earned on them;
A copy of the proposed escrow agreement between the provider and the depository;
Proposed payment arrangements under the agreement for both the shelter and health-related benefits;
A copy of a certificate of need, or a letter or exemption from the certificate of need requirement, issued by MHCC for any proposed comprehensive care beds;
The form and substance of any advertising campaign or proposed advertisement for the proposed project that is available at the time of filing; and
Any further information that the Department requires.

Facilities which offer only domiciliary care or comprehensive care and do not offer independent living units, and facilities which offer, as the only health care, priority admission to a nursing facility, are not subject to §A(17) of this regulation, and shall submit the projection of future population flows and health care bed needs for the first 20 years, using appropriate mortality, morbidity, withdrawal, and other demographic assumptions.
In §A(16)(d) of this regulation, the provider shall submit projected financial statements for a minimum of the first 10 years of operation that include:
Balance sheets;
Income statements, including separate supplemental income statements for each of the following:
Independent living,
Assisted living, and
Comprehensive care;
Statements of cash flow; and

The key assumptions used in preparing the projected financial statements, including assumptions related to utilization, turnover of units, inflation, debt service, personnel staffing and related salaries, interest rates, depreciation and amortization, amortization of entrance fees, raw food, insurance, and real estate taxes.

section.heading: Application for a Preliminary Certificate of Registration.

para.text: Application. An application for a preliminary certificate of registration shall include the information described in this regulation.
The names and addresses of the following shall be included:
The facility;
The provider;
Any affiliate, parent, or subsidiary person or business entity; and
The chief executive officer of the provider, the facility, and each affiliate, parent, or subsidiary person or business entity.
The application shall describe the organizational structure and management of the provider, including:
If the provider is a corporation or limited liability company, the:
Name of the corporation or limited liability company, and
State in which the corporation is incorporated or the limited liability company is formed;
If the provider is a partnership, the:
Names of the general partners,
State governing the formation of the partnership, and
Name of the primary individual responsible for managing the partnership;
If the provider is an unincorporated association, the:
Names of the members,
State governing the association's activities, and
Name of the primary individual responsible for managing the association;
If the provider is a partnership having a corporation or limited liability company as one or more of its general partners, the:
Names of each corporation or limited liability company,
State in which each corporation is incorporated or the limited liability company is formed, and
Name of the chief executive officer of each;
If the provider is a trust, the:
Name of each trustee,
Names of the owners of beneficial interests in the trust,
State whose laws govern the trust, and
Name of the primary individual responsible for overseeing the trust's activities;
The names and occupations of:
The provider's officers, directors, trustees, managing or general partners, and non-stock corporation members, and
An individual having a 10 percent or greater equity or beneficial interest in the provider;
A description of each financial interest in, or occupation with, the provider of each individual identified under §C(6) of this regulation.
Contracts with Related Entities.

If it is anticipated that a business entity will provide to either the facility or the provider goods, premises, or services with a value of $10,000 or more within any fiscal year, and if a person identified in §C(6) of this regulation has a financial interest of 10 percent or more in the business entity, the application shall include:
The name and address of the business entities;
A description of the goods, premises, or services; and
The anticipated yearly costs the facility or provider will incur for the goods, premises, or services.
Section D(1) of this regulation does not require the disclosure of salary, age, or benefit information of employees of the provider.

The application shall include a copy of all current documentation concerning the legal organization of the provider, including the corporate charter, bylaws, partnership agreement, articles of association, membership agreement, trust agreement, or similar instruments or agreements.

The application shall include certified financial statements of the provider for the three most recent fiscal years for which certified financial statements are obtainable under generally accepted accounting principles. If the provider's fiscal year ended more than 90 days before the date of the filing, then the application shall also include an income statement, which does not need to be certified, that covers a period that begins on the date the fiscal year ended and ends on a date that is within 90 days of the date of the filing.

The application shall include a statement of any current or prior affiliation with a religious, charitable, or other nonprofit organization, and the extent, if any, to which the affiliate organization will be responsible for the financial and contractual obligations of the provider.
The application shall include a copy of any proposed:
Agreements to be entered into between the provider and subscribers for continuing care; and
Priority admission agreements between the provider and any health care providers.
A table of the most current fee structure, including escalator or other automatic adjustment provisions, shall accompany the application.
A statement describing the current or proposed use of any insurance program or publicly funded benefit program in the financing of care shall accompany the application.
A description of the physical facility shall accompany the application.

The form and substance of any advertising campaign, advertisement, or other promotional material for the facility that has not been previously filed with the Department shall be submitted with the application.
Any other reasonable and pertinent information that the Department requests in writing shall be submitted with the application.

section.heading: Department Action on Feasibility Study and Application for a Preliminary Certificate of Registration.

para.text: The Department shall approve a feasibility study when it determines that:

Either a certificate of need or an exemption from a certificate of need has been issued by MHCC for the number of comprehensive care beds proposed for the facility for which licenses are required by MDH;
The number of licensed assisted living units proposed for the facility is not inconsistent with the State Health Plan;
A reasonable financial plan has been submitted for developing and operating the proposed project, which:
Includes in the projected financial statements all obligations and liabilities to be undertaken by the provider pursuant to the terms of the proposed continuing care agreement;
Demonstrates that the anticipated sources of funds to finance the proposed project are equal to or greater than the anticipated uses of funds to construct or acquire the proposed project; and
Demonstrates that the facility is financially feasible;
A market for the continuing care facility appears to exist, based on reliable data, which:
Is community specific;
Takes into account competing shelter and health-related providers;
Relates the existence of a market to the age, health, sex, marital status, number, population trends, net worth, home values, and income of the potential subscribers; and
Demonstrates that the rate of penetration in the proposed market area is within acceptable industry ranges;
The actuarial study as required in Regulation .05 of this chapter has been submitted and includes:

A cohort pricing analysis that demonstrates that, for a typical cohort of new subscribers, the sum of the entrance fees paid at occupancy plus the actuarial present value at occupancy of periodic fees exceeds the actuarial present value at occupancy of the costs of performing all obligations assumed by the provider, with appropriate provision for surplus;
Cash flow projections for a 20-year period, which project positive cash balances;
Supporting detailed documentation for the cohort pricing analysis which includes a:
Projection of future population flows for a 20-year period, which uses appropriate morbidity, mortality, withdrawal, and other demographic assumptions,
Projection of future health care bed needs for a 20-year period, which uses appropriate morbidity, mortality, withdrawal, and other demographic assumptions, and
Descriptions of the actuarial data, assumptions, and methods; and
An opinion of a qualified actuary, which states that:
The data and assumptions used are appropriate,
The methods employed are consistent with sound actuarial principles and practices, and
Provision has been made for all actuarial liabilities and related statement items;

The projection of future population flows and health care bed needs, for the first 20 years, uses appropriate mortality, morbidity, withdrawal, and other demographic assumptions as required in Regulation .05 of this chapter;
The feasibility study was prepared by an authority recognized by the Department;
The approved escrow agreement and deposit agreement state that all deposits and entrance fees shall be held in escrow in Maryland in a financial institution until:
The issuance of an initial certificate of registration;
Completion of construction;
The issuance of a certificate of occupancy or the equivalent by the appropriate local jurisdiction; and
The issuance of appropriate licenses or certificates by MDH, MHCC, and the Department; and
A copy of the escrow agreement, executed by the provider and the financial institution, is on file with the Department.
The Department shall issue a preliminary certificate of registration when it determines that the following conditions have been met:
The feasibility study has been approved by the Department;
The agreement between the provider and the subscriber meets the requirements of Human Services Article, §§10-444—10-449, Annotated Code of Maryland, and Regulations .27—.29 of this chapter;
The required financial and organizational materials have been submitted to the Department; and
The Department has determined that the form and substance of all advertising and other promotional materials filed are not deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead.

Until the initial certificate of registration has been issued, the provider shall inform the Department of any changes or additions to the information provided in the feasibility study and in the application for a preliminary certificate of registration.

section.heading: Advertising Before an Initial Certificate of Registration Has Been Issued.

para.text: If a provider that has submitted a feasibility study desires to advertise a continuing care community before an initial certificate of registration has been issued, the provider shall submit that advertising so it is received by the Department at least 3 working days before the advertising is to be aired, distributed, or otherwise used. The envelope or package in which the submission is delivered shall indicate in prominent type that the contents are proposed advertising materials for a community that does not have an initial certificate of registration.

The Department shall determine within 3 working days of the receipt of the advertising whether it is deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead. If the Department determines that the advertising is deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead and should not be used, then the Department shall notify the provider that submitted the advertising materials of its determination. This notice shall be in writing, include the rationale for the determination, and be delivered before the close of business of the third working day after the day upon which the advertising was received for review. The notice may be delivered by facsimile.

If the provider has not received the notice by 5 p.m. on the third working day following receipt of the advertising by the Department, the provider may use the advertising. The lack of notification by the Department does not mean the Department has determined that the advertising is not deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead.

If a provider is notified that the Department has determined that the advertising, or some part of the advertising, is deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead, the provider may appeal that determination under Regulation .36 of this chapter. An appeal shall be processed on an accelerated basis if the provider so desires.

section.heading: Application for an Initial Certificate of Registration.

para.text: A provider shall file an application for an initial certificate of registration on a form provided by the Department.
The application shall include verification that:
All licenses and certificates required as of the date of the application from MDH, MHCC, and the Department for the new units have been issued;
Agreements have been executed for at least 65 percent of the independent living units and at least 10 percent of the total entrance fees for each contracted unit has been collected;
The provider has received a written commitment for permanent long-term financing; and
Closing on construction financing has taken place.

A provider may, when the requirements in §B(1)—(3) of this regulation have been met, request the Department to verify to its construction lender that these requirements have been met to the Department's satisfaction, and that an initial certificate of registration for the new units will be issued when closing on the construction loan has taken place.

section.heading: Action of Department on Application for an Initial Certificate of Registration.

para.text: The Department shall issue an initial certificate of registration when it determines that all of the following conditions have been met:
The provider has been issued a preliminary certificate of registration;
The provider has received all licenses and certifications and letters of exemption required as of that date from MDH, MHCC, and the Department;
The provider has submitted documentation which demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Department that:
Agreements have been executed for at least 65 percent of the independent living units, and
At least 10 percent of the total entrance fee has been paid as a deposit for each unit for which an agreement has been executed;
The provider has submitted documentation to the satisfaction of the Department that there is a commitment for permanent long-term financing;
The provider has submitted documentation which demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Department that closing on construction financing has taken place; and
The form and substance of all advertising and other promotional materials filed are not deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead.

If requested, a verification letter may be issued to the construction lender by the Department when it is determined that the conditions stated in §A(1)—(4), and (6) of this regulation have been met and that an initial certificate of registration will be issued for the new units when closing on the construction loan has taken place.

If the conditions in §A of this regulation are not met, the Department shall issue a denial of an initial certificate of registration, in writing, which includes the reasons for the denial. The provider may resubmit an amended application within the time limits set forth in §D of this regulation.

If an initial certificate of registration is not issued within 24 months of the issuance of the preliminary certificate of registration, or a longer time allowed by the Department for good cause shown, as defined in §E of this regulation, the Department shall require the provider to refund all deposits and to cease in its attempts to offer continuing care under that application. A further intent to provide continuing care shall require a new application, including a feasibility study.
The Department may not deny a request for an extension of time if the provider demonstrates reasonable progress toward acquiring an initial certificate of registration.

section.heading: Request for Approval to Use Deposits.

para.text: After the issuance of an initial certificate of registration for any new units, the provider may submit to the Department a request for permission to use deposits.
The request shall include verification that:
Construction of the proposed project has been completed as evidenced by a certificate of substantial completion; and
The provider has been issued:
A certificate of occupancy, or the equivalent, by the appropriate local jurisdiction, and
The appropriate licenses or certificates required by MDH, MHCC, and the Department.

section.heading: Action of the Department on Request for Approval to Use Deposits.
section.text: The Department shall issue a written approval to the provider permitting withdrawal of deposits from escrow for use by the provider when the Department determines that the provider has met the following requirements:

para.text: Construction of the proposed project has been completed as evidenced by a certificate of substantial completion;
A certificate of occupancy, or its equivalent, has been issued by the appropriate local jurisdiction;
An initial certificate of registration has been issued for any new units; and
Appropriate licenses or certificates required by MDH, MHCC, and the Department have been issued.

section.heading: Application for Renewal Certificate of Registration.

para.text: The provider shall file an application for a renewal certificate of registration within 120 days of the end of the provider's fiscal year on a form provided by the Department.

A renewal certificate of registration shall be issued for 1 year, which is in effect from 6 months after the end of the provider's most recent fiscal year to 6 months after the close of the provider's current fiscal year.
The application for a renewal certificate of registration shall include the following information and attachments:
Any changes or additions to the information submitted on the most recent application;

An original certified financial statement for the preceding fiscal year prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, which include the principles expressed in the American Institute of Certified Public Accounts' "Audit and Accounting Guide for Health Care Organizations";
All exhibits or attachments to the certified financial statements, including:
A balance sheet,
An income statement,
A statement of cash flows,
The related notes to the financial statements, and
The opinion of an independent certified public accountant;
An operating budget for the current fiscal year prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
A projection of the number of subscribers who will require nursing home care and an estimate of the life expectancy of future subscribers;
A projected operating budget for the next succeeding fiscal year prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principals;
An actuarial study which meets the requirements of §E of this regulation;
A report specifying:
The total current number of units,
Whether each unit is occupied or unoccupied, and
Changes in unit configurations proposed for the succeeding year;
A copy of each current license and certificate required to be issued by MDH or the Department;
A copy of the provider's most recent certificate of need or exemption letter from MHCC;
The form and substance of any advertising campaign or proposed advertisement and other promotional materials not previously filed with the Department;
A renewal fee of $29 per unit;
A cash flow projection for the current fiscal year and the next 2 fiscal years prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
A statement that provides the dates of the meetings held the previous year to comply with Regulation .19 of this chapter;
A copy of the disclosure statement prepared in accordance with Regulation .21 of this chapter; and
A statement that indicates compliance with the operating reserve requirement in Regulation .20 of this chapter.
Actuarial Study Exceptions.
Until January 1, 1999, §E of this regulation does not apply to facilities which offer only domiciliary care or comprehensive care and do not offer independent living units.
Section E of this regulation does not apply to a facility:
Where the only health care provided to subscribers is either priority admission to an independent nursing facility or paid for on a fee-for-service basis;
Where:
The provider is in the process of decertifying as a provider; and
Fewer than five of the facility's subscribers have continuing care agreements that promise the provider will provide more than 90 days of nursing care on a basis other than fee-for-service; or
Where:
The comprehensive care facility is Medicaid certified;
The continuing care agreements presently offered new subscribers only provide nursing care on a fee-for-service basis, and
5 percent or less of the facility's subscribers have continuing care agreements that promise the provider will provide nursing care on a basis other than fee-for-service.
Actuarial Study.

Unless exempted by §D of this regulation, every 3 years after occupancy of the facility has begun, a provider shall submit to the Department with its renewal application an actuarial study, prepared or reviewed by a qualified actuary. The actuarial study shall include:
An actuarial balance sheet for current subscribers;
A cohort pricing analysis for a cohort of new subscribers; and
Projected cash and investment balances for a period of 20 years.

The actuarial study required by §E(1) of this regulation shall be performed in accordance with generally accepted actuarial principles and the standards of practice adopted by the Actuarial Standards Board of the American Academy of Actuaries. The actuarial study shall include or be accompanied by a statement of the opinion of a qualified actuary as to whether:
The data and assumptions used are appropriate;
The methods employed are consistent with sound actuarial principles and practices;
Provision has been made for all actuarial liabilities and related statement items; and
The provider is in satisfactory actuarial balance.

The actuarial study shall include supporting detailed documentation, including a projection of future population flows and health care bed needs for 20 years using appropriate inflation factors, mortality, morbidity, withdrawal, and other demographic assumptions.

The Department may request the information required in §E(1)(3) of this regulation more frequently to assist in the determination of possible financial difficulty as provided in Regulation .26 of this chapter.

If the materials required in §C of this regulation are not received in the Department within 120 days after the end of the provider's fiscal year, the Department may charge a late fee of $10 per unit in addition to the renewal fee per unit, unless a written request for an extension is submitted to and approved by the Department within the 120-day period.
Failure to file the annual renewal application or obtain an extension within 120 days after the end of a fiscal year is a violation of the Act and this chapter.

section.heading: Action of the Department on Application for Annual Renewal Certificate of Registration.

para.text: The Department shall approve an application for a renewal certificate of registration when it determines that:
The required documents have been filed;
Any revised agreements meet the applicable requirements of the Act and this chapter;
The provider has not been found to be in financial difficulty;
The necessary facilities for providing continuing care are in existence;
The provider has received all required licenses and certificates from MDH, MHCC, and the Department;
The form and substance of all advertising and other promotional materials filed are not deceptive, misleading, or likely to mislead;
If required under Regulation .13 of this chapter, an actuarial study, prepared or reviewed by a qualified actuary, has been submitted which meets the requirements of Regulation .13E of this chapter;
The disclosure statement submitted complies with Regulation .21 of this chapter;
The operating reserves comply with the requirements of Regulation .20 of this chapter; and
All renewal fees and any late fees have been paid.

Upon review of a provider's application for a renewal certificate of registration, the Department may make a finding of possible financial difficulty. The Department may refer the application of a provider found to be in possible financial difficulty to the Financial Review Committee. Applications that are referred to the Committee are subject to Regulations .25 and .26 of this chapter.

If the conditions in §A of this regulation and, if applicable, Regulation .26 of this chapter are not met, the Department may issue in writing a denial of an application for a renewal certificate of registration. The Department shall include the reasons for denying an application in the written denial.

If the actuary responsible for an actuarial study required by Regulation .13E of this chapter does not opine that the provider is in satisfactory actuarial balance, the provider shall submit to the Department with its renewal application a detailed plan that specifies how and when the provider plans to attain satisfactory actuarial balance.

section.heading: Application for Renovation of Facility.

para.text: Statement of Intent. A provider that intends to undertake a renovation of its facility shall file a statement of intent with the Department at least 30 days before submitting a renovation approval request. If a renovation approval request is not filed by the provider within 60 days after the statement of intent is filed, a new statement of intent shall be filed with the Department at least 30 days before submission of a financial plan described in §B of this regulation. The statement of intent shall describe at a minimum the nature of the renovation.
Renovation Approval Request. A request for renovation approval shall:
Be prepared in a form satisfactory to the Department; and
Include at least the following information:
A statement of the purpose and need for the renovation;
A financial plan, prepared by an authority recognized by the Department, that:
Meets the requirements of §C of this regulation, and

Demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Department that the renovation will not have an unreasonably adverse effect on the financial ability of the provider to furnish continuing care in accordance with the provider's agreements and the Act at each facility of the provider in the State; and
Any further information the Department requires.
Financial Plan. A financial plan shall include:
The anticipated costs of the proposed renovation, including:
Construction costs,
Architect and engineering fees,
Financing costs,
Legal and administrative costs, and
Any other related costs;
The anticipated sources and uses of funds to finance the proposed renovation;
A description of any proposed financing, including anticipated terms and costs of financing;
Projected 5-year cash flow statements prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles; and
The key assumptions underlying the cash flow statements.

section.heading: Action of the Department on Renovation Approval Request.

para.text: Approval Standards. The Department shall approve a renovation approval request when it determines that a reasonable financial plan, prepared by an authority recognized by the Department, has been submitted for the proposed renovation, and the plan demonstrates that:
The anticipated sources of funds to finance the proposed renovation are equal to or greater than the anticipated uses of funds for the proposed renovation; and

The proposed renovation will not have an unreasonably adverse effect on the financial ability of the provider to furnish continuing care in accordance with the provider's agreements and the Act at each facility of the provider in the State.

No Construction Before Approval. A provider may not begin construction of a renovation until the provider receives written approval of the renovation approval request from the Department for the proposed renovation.

section.heading: Application for Expansion of Facility.

para.text: Statement of Intent.
A provider that intends to undertake an expansion of its facility shall file a statement of intent with the Department at least 30 days before submission of an expansion approval request.

If the expansion approval request is not filed by the provider within 60 days after the statement of intent is filed, a new statement of intent shall be filed with the Department at least 30 days before submission of the financial plan described in §B(3) of this regulation.
A statement of intent shall describe at a minimum:
The proposed expansion;
The types of agreements proposed, such as extensive, modified, or fee-for-service, and whether entrance fees will be refundable or nonrefundable;
The number of proposed additional units, if any, by unit type; and
Any further information the Department requires.
Expansion Approval Request.
An expansion approval request shall be prepared in a form satisfactory to the Department.
A provider's expansion approval request shall include the following information:
A statement of the purpose and need for the expansion;
A demonstration that a market exists for any proposed additional independent living or assisted living units, which meets the requirements of §C of this regulation; and
A financial plan that:
Is prepared by an authority recognized by the Department,

Demonstrates to the satisfaction of the Department that the expansion will not have an unreasonably adverse effect on the financial ability of the provider to furnish continuing care in accordance with the provider's agreements and the Act at each facility of the provider in the State, and
Meets the requirements of §D of this regulation.
Demonstration of a Market.
For expansions of ten or fewer units, a provider's expansion approval request shall include the following to demonstrate that a market exists for the proposed additional units:
The existing wait lists and existing occupancy lists for the facility's independent living and assisted living units, by unit type; or
Other documentation of market demand for the proposed additional units that is acceptable to the Department.
For expansions of more than ten units, a provider's expansion approval request shall include the following to demonstrate that a market exists for the proposed additional units:
A description of the primary and secondary market areas as defined by the provider;

A table of population information, including the age, sex, number, income distribution, and trends of the total population and of the population of individuals 60 years old and older within the primary and secondary market areas;
A calculation of the market penetration rate for the proposed additional units for both the primary and secondary markets;
A table of home values in the primary and secondary market areas; and
A statement of the minimum age, income, and net worth eligibility standards for a subscriber to the proposed additional living units.
Financial Plan. A financial plan required in §B(2)(c) of this regulation shall include:
The anticipated costs of the proposed expansion, including all related costs such as:
Financing costs,
Marketing costs,
Construction costs,
Architect and engineering fees,
Legal and administrative costs, and
Any other costs;
The anticipated sources and uses of funds to finance the proposed expansion and costs of financing;
A description of any proposed financing, including anticipated terms;
Projected 5-year balance sheets, income statements, cash flow statements, including key assumptions for each, prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
A schedule of anticipated periodic fees and entrance fees for any additional independent living and assisted living units;
A schedule of monthly move-ins, by unit type, for any additional units; and
Any further information the Department requires.
Filing Fee.
A filing fee of $50 per additional unit shall accompany the expansion approval request.
The Department may charge an additional fee, not to exceed the original fee, for resubmission of a financial plan to the Department due to:
Significant changes in assumptions in the financial plan;
Correction of significant errors in the plan; or
An incomplete financial plan submission.

section.heading: Action of the Department on Expansion Approval Request.

para.text: The Department shall approve an expansion approval request and, if applicable, issue a revised certificate of registration that includes the additional units when it determines that:
A market for the additional independent living and assisted living units appears to exist, based on reliable data; and
A reasonable financial plan, prepared by an authority recognized by the Department, has been submitted for the proposed expansion that demonstrates that the:
Anticipated sources of funds to finance the proposed expansion are equal to or greater than the anticipated uses of funds for the proposed expansion, and

Proposed expansion will not have an unreasonably adverse effect on the financial ability of the provider to furnish continuing care in accordance with the provider's agreements and the Act at each facility of the provider in the State.
A provider may not begin construction of the expansion until the provider receives written approval from the Department for the proposed expansion.

section.heading: Required Information Regarding Governance.

para.text: In General. At least annually, each provider shall conduct a meeting, open to all of the provider's subscribers, at which an authorized officer of the provider shall present a summary of the provider's operations, significant changes from the previous year, and goals and objectives for the next year. The provider shall make provisions to have an authorized officer receive and answer questions from subscribers at the meeting.
Provider that has a Governing Body.
A provider that has a governing body shall include at least one of the provider's subscribers as a full and regular member of the governing body.

If a provider that has a governing body owns or operates more than three facilities in the State, there shall be at least one of the provider's subscribers as a full and regular member of the governing body for every three facilities in the State.
Subscriber Member Selection Requirements.

Subject to the provisions of §B(3)(b) of this regulation, a governing body member selected to meet the requirements of §B(1) and (2) of this regulation shall be a subscriber at a facility in the State and be selected according to the same general written standards and criteria used to select other members of the governing body.
The governing body shall confer with the subscriber association at each facility of the provider before the subscriber officially joins the governing body.

Provider Without a Governing Body. A provider that does not have a governing body shall appoint a select committee of its officers or partners to meet at least twice annually with the subscriber association at each of its facilities to address concerns of the subscribers and to ensure that the opinions of subscribers are relayed to all officers or partners of the provider. If a facility does not have an association of subscribers, the committee shall meet with a reasonable number of representatives, not required to exceed 15, elected by the subscribers.

Materials to be Made Available. Copies of all materials that a provider submits to the Department that are required to be disclosed under the Public Information Act shall be made readily available by the provider for its subscribers to review at the facility.

section.heading: Operating Reserve Requirements.

para.text: Definitions.
In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Binding agreement" means an unconditional, irrevocable letter of credit or line of credit agreement entered into by a provider and a financial institution.

"Debt service fund" means one or more special loan funds, established under requirements imposed by a financial institution or under applicable financing documents, into which the provider is required to deposit moneys during the provider's fiscal year to pay the current portion of the principal due and the interest accruing in that year on the provider's debt.

"Debt service reserve fund" means moneys required by a financial institution or under applicable financing documents to be deposited in a special loan fund, which are to be used to pay principal and interest payments due on the provider's debt if the provider is unable to pay when due the principal and interest from operating income or other sources.
"Market value" means readily determinable fair value.
Net Operating Expenses.

"Net operating expenses" means a provider's total operating expenses at each facility of the provider, less depreciation, amortization, unusual and infrequent expenses, and changes in the obligation to provide future services.

"Net operating expenses" does not include interest expense if the provider has funded a debt service fund or other interest reserve under requirements imposed by a financial institution or under applicable financing documents, to the extent and in the amount the fund or reserve includes amounts to cover interest for the year in question.
"Other interest reserve" means one or more special loan funds other than debt service funds or debt service reserve funds:
Established under requirements imposed by a financial institution or under applicable financing documents; and
Into which the provider is required to deposit moneys during the provider's fiscal year to pay interest accruing in that year on the provider's debt.
Computation of Operating Reserve Requirement.

Except as otherwise provided in this regulation, a provider shall set aside for each facility subject to this chapter operating reserves equal to 15 percent of the facility's net operating expenses for the most recent fiscal year for which a certified financial statement is available. The reserves shall be maintained in reasonably liquid form in the judgment of the provider and in accordance with the provider's investment policies.

A provider shall compute operating reserves for each facility as of the end of the facility's most recent fiscal year and shall indicate compliance by setting forth the amount actually set aside in a letter to the Department from the provider's certified public accountant or by disclosing the amount in the provider's most recent certified financial statement. The letter or certified financial statements shall be submitted with the provider's application for a renewal certificate.

A provider may apply toward the reserve required by this regulation any reserves, other than debt service reserve funds, maintained under applicable financing document requirements if the reserves are available to the provider to meet the facility's operating expenses.

For the purpose of calculating the provider's operating reserves, investments held to the credit of the reserves shall be calculated at their market value as of the end of the provider's most recent fiscal year for which a certified financial statement is available.

A provider at a community that has not been the subject of a conversion and in which some residents are not parties to continuing care agreements shall set aside as its operating reserves an amount equal to at least 15 percent of the pro rata proportion of the net operating expenses for the community. The pro rata proportion of the net operating expenses shall equal the number of units in the community certified by the Department divided by the total number of accommodations in the community, with the resulting figure multiplied by the net operating expenses for the community for the most recent fiscal year for which a certified financial statement is available.

In calculating the community's operating expenses, the provider may deduct depreciation, amortization, unusual and infrequent expenses, and changes in the obligation to provide future services. Interest expense may also be excluded from the calculation of operating expenses if the provider has funded a debt service fund or other interest reserve under requirements imposed by a financial institution or under applicable financing documents, to the extent and in the amount the fund or reserve includes amounts to cover interest for the year in question.
Use of Operating Reserves.
A provider shall notify the Department in writing simultaneously with drawing any amount from the funds available to satisfy the operating reserve that is required by §B of this regulation.
Within 30 days of any draw, the provider shall submit to the Department a written plan for restoring the funds in the reserve to the level required by §B of this regulation.
Phase-In Period of Operating Reserve Requirement.

A provider shall have up to 10 full fiscal years after the later of October 1, 1996, or the date of its first initial certificate of registration for the community, to meet the requirement of §B of this regulation.

A provider shall meet the requirement of §B of this regulation at a minimum rate of 10 percent per year as of the end of each fiscal year after the later of October 1, 1996, or the date of its first initial certificate of registration for the community, up to a total of 100 percent as of the end of the tenth fiscal year.

The Department may allow a provider to modify the minimum rate or authorize an additional amount of time to meet the requirement of §B of this regulation if the modification is necessary to maintain the financial viability of the facility.

section.heading: Disclosure Statement.

para.text: General. A provider shall furnish, without cost, a disclosure statement for each facility of the provider holding either a preliminary certificate of registration or a certificate of registration to all prospective subscribers and, upon request, annually to all subscribers. A disclosure statement shall be provided to a prospective subscriber before payment of any part of the entrance fee or, if earlier, the execution of a continuing care agreement. The provider shall submit its initial disclosure statement to the Department for review at least 45 days before distributing the statement to any prospective or existing subscribers.

Disclosure Statement Revisions. A provider shall revise its disclosure statement annually. A provider shall file a revised disclosure statement with the Department within 120 days after the end of the provider's fiscal year and notify current subscribers that the revised disclosure statement is available for review. The Department shall review the disclosure statement solely to ensure compliance with this regulation.
Disclosure Statement Contents. The disclosure statement shall include:
The name and address of the facility;
A description of the facility;
The name and address of any parent or subsidiary person;
The organizational structure and management of the provider, including:
If the provider is a corporation or limited liability company, the:
Name of the corporation or limited liability company,
State in which the corporation is incorporated or the limited liability company is formed, and
Name of the chief executive officer;
If the provider is a partnership, the:
Names of the general partners,
State governing the formation of the partnership, and
Name of the primary individual responsible for managing the partnership;
If the provider is an unincorporated association, the:
Names of the members,
State governing the association's activities, and
Name of the primary individual responsible for managing the association;
If the provider is a partnership having a corporation or limited liability company as one or more of its general partners, the:
Name of each corporation or limited liability company,
State in which the corporation is incorporated or the limited liability company is formed, and
Name of the chief executive officer;
If the provider is a trust, the:
Name of each trustee,
Names of the owners of beneficial interests in the trust,
State whose law governs the trust, and
Name of the primary individual responsible for overseeing the trust's activities; and
A statement regarding whether the provider is qualified, or intends to qualify, as a tax-exempt organization under the Internal Revenue Code;

A statement regarding any affiliation of the provider with a religious, charitable, or other nonprofit organization, and the extent to which that organization is responsible for the financial and contractual obligations of the provider;
A description of all fees collected by the provider that are not optional, including:
Entrance fees;
Fees for health-related services;
Parking fees; and
Periodic fees;
The date and the amount of any changes in the fees that are not optional imposed in any of the past 5 years during which the facility was in operation;
A statement describing provisions that have been, or will be, made to comply with the operating reserve requirements in Regulation .20 of this chapter;
A general statement regarding the provider's investment policy related to the required reserves, including how often the reserve fund investment is reviewed and by whom;
A copy of the most recent certified financial statement available under generally accepted accounting principles;
A description of the long-term financing for the facility;
If operations have not begun at the facility, a summary of the most recent feasibility study approved by the Department, which shall include:
A description of the anticipated sources and uses of funds for the purchase or construction of the facility, including related costs such as:
Land costs,
Construction costs,
Architect and engineering fees,
Financing expenses,
Marketing costs,
Legal and administrative costs, and
Furnishing and equipment costs;

A description of any short-term or long-term financing used in acquiring or constructing the facility, including the terms and costs of the financing or, if the provider leases the facility, a description of the anticipated or actual terms of the lease;

The projected balance sheets, income statements, and cash flow statements of the provider contained in the feasibility study approved by the Department or, if there have been revisions to these financial projections since approval was received, then:
Include the most current projections, and
Specify that the financial projections have been revised since the feasibility study was approved by the Department;
A projected presales schedule for the independent living units;
A projected move-in schedule for all of the units of the facility;
A statement indicating when the provider expects to have executed agreements for 65 percent of the provider's independent living units;
A statement indicating when the provider expects to achieve 95 percent occupancy of the facility's independent living units; and
Any further information the Department requires;

If operations have begun at the facility and the provider has not reached 85 percent occupancy in the independent living units, a summary of the most recent feasibility study approved by the Department, which shall include:
A description of the sources and uses of funds for the purchase or construction of the facility, including related costs such as:
Land costs,
Construction costs,
Architect and engineering fees,
Financing expenses,
Marketing costs,
Legal and administrative costs, and
Furnishing and equipment costs;

A description of any short-term or long-term financing used in acquiring or constructing the facility, including the terms and costs of financing, or, if the provider leases the facility, a description of the terms of the lease;

The projected balance sheets, income statements and cash flow statements of the provider shown in the feasibility study approved by the Department or, if there have been revisions to these financial projections since approval was received, then:
Include the most current projections, and
Specify that the financial projections have been revised since the feasibility study was approved by the Department;
A projected presales schedule for the independent living units;
A projected move-in schedule for all of the units of the facility;
A semiannual schedule which shows actual move-ins for all of the units of the facility since opening;
A statement indicating when the provider expects to achieve 95 percent occupancy of the facility's independent living units; and
Any further information the Department requires;
A cash flow forecast statement for the current and the next 2 fiscal years;
The names and occupations of:
The provider's officers, directors, trustees, and managing or general partners; and
Any person with a 10 percent or greater equity or beneficial interest in the provider;
A description of the financial interest in or occupation with the provider of each person identified under §C(15) of this regulation;

If it is anticipated that a business entity will provide to either the facility or the provider goods, premises, or services with a value of $10,000 or more within any fiscal year, and if a person identified in §C(15) of this regulation has a financial interest of 10 percent or more in the business entity, then include:
The name and address of the business entities;
A description of the goods, premises, or services; and
The anticipated yearly costs the facility or provider will incur for the goods, premises, or services;
